topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Lenny introduces Deb Liu’s career highlights (PayPal/eBay, Facebook VP Product, Ancestry CEO) and frames the episode as tactical career and product-building advice from a product leader at heart.

topics.title: Always be learning: balancing learning and impact
topics.summary: Deb’s core career advice is to always be learning, alternating between roles where you can deliver impact and roles where you’re a beginner again. She emphasizes careers are non-linear and continuous improvement beats being today’s expert.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor messages for Pendo (product experience platform) and WorkOS (enterprise SaaS features like SSO/SCIM and authorization).

topics.title: Breaking into PM: PayPal origin story
topics.summary: Deb shares how she accidentally entered product management at PayPal by leaning on deep user passion and curiosity, then learning the craft on the job. Key takeaway: you don’t need perfect PM process knowledge to start—bring insight into the problem and customers.

topics.title: Interviewing without experience: passion over process
topics.summary: They discuss “fake it till you make it” and Deb reframes it as showing authentic passion for the product/problem rather than pretending to know PM artifacts. She stresses falling in love with the problem and demonstrating customer understanding.

topics.title: Resilience: adversity creates stronger leaders
topics.summary: Deb argues the most successful people aren’t those with charmed careers but those who turn failures and hard feedback into growth. Resilience—bouncing back and learning—is portrayed as a key differentiator for long-term success.

topics.title: Failure Corner: denied dream role at Facebook
topics.summary: Deb recounts being told by Mark Zuckerberg she’d never get a role she wanted, and how she chose to transform the job she had into the job she wanted. The lesson: you’re not right for every role, and agency comes from shaping what you control.

topics.title: Building zero-to-one inside Facebook: tactics and reality
topics.summary: Deb explains her path building new businesses (games/payments, direct-response mobile ads) and how iteration, multiple near-death moments, and minimal early scrutiny/resources are often necessary. She highlights the high failure rate and the need to prune/pivot quickly.

topics.title: Creating space for innovation: patience and portfolio thinking
topics.summary: They discuss how leaders can support innovation by being patient and treating new bets as a portfolio with expected failures. Deb contrasts core-product incremental growth with new-product work where a 50% hit rate is considered strong.

topics.title: Career bet selection: when to take big swings
topics.summary: Deb advises early-career PMs to first build core skills in stable areas, then later allocate 2–3 years to a high-risk “big swing” that can define career narratives. The tradeoff is resume certainty versus trajectory-changing outcomes.

topics.title: PM your career: write a spec and metrics
topics.summary: Deb argues many great PMs drift in their careers without goals, milestones, or metrics, and should manage careers with the same intentionality as products. She shares her own largely accidental path as a cautionary tale about relying on luck and mentors.

topics.title: Direction vs rigidity: aiming your career thoughtfully
topics.summary: They explore balancing planning with openness—having a direction and a measuring stick for serial job decisions without over-grasping outcomes. Deb shares an example of mentoring someone who worked backward from a board-seat goal into concrete steps.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor message for Webflow (visual-first platform to build, launch, and optimize webpages quickly).

topics.title: Introverts at work: bias, visibility, and inclusive practices
topics.summary: Deb discusses how workplaces reward speaking up, which can hide introverts’ impact, and shares tactics like structured round-robin input and offline voting docs to equalize voices. She frames leadership as both adapting personally and redesigning systems to reduce bias.

topics.title: Speaking up as a learnable skill, not self-promotion
topics.summary: Deb argues introverts must treat communication as a necessary, learnable leadership skill and reframe “self-promotion” as educating others and advocating for team resources. They discuss discomfort with performative LinkedIn-style posting and how reframing can unlock visibility.
